subject: Physics

figures.description: Transformer core with primary (Input) and secondary (Output) windings. Used in Question 2.
Circuit containing a cell (internal resistance negligible) connected to two resistors 3Ω and 6Ω in parallel; total current marked 4.0 A. Used in Question 8.
Plank RS pivoted at O (centre of gravity) with weights P and Q hanging at different positions. Used in Question 10.
Refraction diagram with angles marked 30° and 60° around a boundary and medium labeled M. Used in Question 16.
Series a.c. circuit diagram with inductor L and resistor R showing Vr = 6V and VL = 8V (r.m.s). Used in Question 21.
Vector triangle diagram with vectors P (vertical), Q (lower slant), and R (upper slant) forming a closed shape. Used in Question 24.

questions.question: What is the least possible error encountered when taking measurement with a meter rule?
questions.explanation: A metre rule has a smallest division of 1 mm. The least possible reading error is half the smallest division: \(\pm 0.5\,\text{mm}\).

questions.question: The electromotive force in the secondary winding is
questions.explanation: A transformer operates on alternating magnetic flux, so the induced emf in the secondary is alternating with time (i.e., varying).

questions.question: If a pump is capable of lifting 5000 kg of water through a vertical height of 60 in 15 mins, the power of the pump is
questions.explanation: Work done \(W=mgh\). Taking \(g\approx 10\,m s^{-2}\): \(W=5000\times 10\times 60=3.0\times 10^6\,J\). Time \(t=15\,min=900\,s\). Power \(P=W/t=\frac{3.0\times 10^6}{900}=3.33\times 10^3\,W\approx 3.3\times 10^3\,J s^{-1}\).

questions.question: Calculate the temperature change when 500 J of heat is supplied to 100 g of water.
questions.explanation: Using \(\Delta T=\frac{Q}{mc}\) with \(m=0.1\,kg\), \(c=4200\,J kg^{-1}K^{-1}\): \(\Delta T=\frac{500}{0.1\times 4200}=1.19\,K\approx 1.2^{\circ}C\).

questions.question: Which of the following particles CANNOT be deflected by both electric and magnetic fields?
questions.explanation: Gamma rays are uncharged electromagnetic radiation, so they are not deflected by electric or magnetic fields.

questions.question: Under which of the following conditions do gasses conduct electricity?
questions.explanation: Gas conduction requires ionization, which is achieved most readily at low pressure with sufficiently high potential difference.

questions.question: Dispersion occurs when white light passes through a glass prism because of the

options.text: different speeds of the colour in the glass
different hidden colours in the glass

questions.explanation: Different wavelengths travel at different speeds (different refractive indices) in glass, causing different refractions and hence dispersion.

questions.question: Calculate the e.m.f of the cell in the above circuit if its internal resistance is negligible.
questions.explanation: The 3Ω and 6Ω resistors are in parallel: \(\frac{1}{R_{eq}}=\frac{1}{3}+\frac{1}{6}=\frac{1}{2}\Rightarrow R_{eq}=2\,\Omega\). Total current is 4.0 A, so \(E=IR_{eq}=4\times 2=8\,V\).

questions.question: An object of mass 80 kg is pulled on a horizontal rough ground by a force of 500 N. Find the coefficient of static friction. [\(g\approx 10\,m s^{-2}\)]
questions.explanation: At limiting equilibrium, frictional force \(F_f = \mu_s N\). On a horizontal surface, \(N=mg=80\times 10=800\,N\). If the pulling force is just balanced by maximum static friction, \(500=\mu_s\times 800\Rightarrow \mu_s=\frac{500}{800}=0.625\). This is closest to 0.6 (A), not 0.4. Since only one answer is expected but no option equals 0.625, the nearest option is A.

questions.question: The diagram above shows plank RS pivoted at its centre of gravity O and is in equilibrium with the weights P and Q. If a weight 2P is added to P, the plank will be in equilibrium again by

options.text: adding a weight Q to Q
moving P further away from O

questions.explanation: Initial equilibrium implies moments about O balance: \(P d_P = Q d_Q\). Adding 2P makes left moment larger; to restore balance, reduce the left moment by reducing its lever arm, i.e., move P nearer to O.

questions.question: A glass plate 0.9 cm thick has a refractive index of 1.50. How long does it take for a pulse of light to pass through the plate? [\(c=3.0\times 10^8\,m s^{-1}\)]
questions.explanation: Speed in glass \(v=\frac{c}{n}=\frac{3.0\times 10^8}{1.5}=2.0\times 10^8\,m s^{-1}\). Thickness \(d=0.9\,cm=9.0\times 10^{-3}\,m\). Time \(t=\frac{d}{v}=\frac{9.0\times 10^{-3}}{2.0\times 10^8}=4.5\times 10^{-11}\,s\). This matches option B, not A.

questions.question: The main purpose of the transformer in an a.c radio set is to

options.text: convert energy from a.c. to d.c

questions.explanation: In an a.c. radio set, the transformer is used to reduce the mains voltage to a lower value suitable for the circuit.

questions.question: The energy associated with the emitted photon when a mercury atom changes from one state to another is 3.3 eV. Calculate the frequency of the photon.
questions.explanation: Convert energy: \(E=3.3\,eV=3.3\times 1.6\times 10^{-19}=5.28\times 10^{-19}\,J\). Frequency \(f=\frac{E}{h}=\frac{5.28\times 10^{-19}}{6.63\times 10^{-34}}\approx 7.96\times 10^{14}\,Hz\). The provided options are of order \(10^{-53}\,Hz\), which is inconsistent; therefore none matches.

questions.question: \(^{235}_{92}U + ^{1}_{0}n \rightarrow ^{144}_{56}Ba + ^{90}_{36}Kr + 2X\). In the reaction above, X is
questions.explanation: Conserve mass number: left \(235+1=236\). Right \(144+90=234\), so 2 units missing → two neutrons, hence \(X\) is a neutron.

questions.question: To protect a material from the influence of an external magnetic field, the material should be kept in a
questions.explanation: Soft iron provides magnetic shielding by offering a low-reluctance path for magnetic field lines.

questions.question: The refractive index of the medium M in the diagram above is
questions.explanation: From the diagram, the angle to the normal in air is 60° and in medium M is 30°. Using Snell’s law with air \(n\approx 1\): \(n_M = \frac{\sin 60^\circ}{\sin 30^\circ}=\frac{\sqrt{3}/2}{1/2}=\sqrt{3}\). That would be option B, but the diagram labels are ambiguous (both 60° markings are visible). If instead the refracted angle is 60° in M and incident is 30° in air, then \(n_M=\frac{\sin 30^\circ}{\sin 60^\circ}=\frac{1/2}{\sqrt{3}/2}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\) (option C). Because the angle labels are not unambiguous in the upload, a unique choice cannot be made.

questions.question: Thermal equilibrium between two objects exists when

options.text: the heat capacities of both objects are the same
the quantity of heat in both objects are the same
the temperature of both objects are equal
one object loses heat continuously to the other

questions.explanation: Thermal equilibrium means no net heat flow, which occurs when both objects have the same temperature.

questions.question: Which of the following is a characteristic of stationary waves?

options.text: The antinode is a point of minimum displacement.
The distance between two successive nodes is one wavelength.
They can be transverse or longitudinal
They are formed by two identical waves travelling in opposite directions.

questions.explanation: Stationary waves are produced by superposition of two waves of equal frequency and amplitude travelling in opposite directions.

questions.question: The height at which the atmosphere ceases to exist is about 80 km. If the atmospheric pressure at a height of 20 km above the ground level is
questions.explanation: The question is incomplete in the provided image: it gives a reference height (80 km) but does not provide the model/relationship needed (e.g., linear decrease assumption, sea-level pressure value) to compute pressure at 20 km unambiguously.

questions.question: A metal of mass 0.5 kg is heated to 100°C and then transferred to a well-lagged calorimeter of heat capacity 80 J K^-1 containing water of heat capacity ... The heat capacity of the metal is
questions.explanation: The question statement is cut off in the image (missing the water heat capacity value and likely initial/final temperatures), so the metal’s specific heat capacity cannot be determined.

questions.instruction: Use the series a.c. circuit diagram (figure Phy2016_Q21_AC_RL_VectorDiagram).
questions.question: In the series a.c circuit shown below, the p.d across the inductor is 8 V r.m.s. The effective voltage is
questions.explanation: From the diagram, \(V_L=8\,V\) and \(V_R=6\,V\). In a series RL circuit, \(V=\sqrt{V_R^2+V_L^2}=\sqrt{6^2+8^2}=\sqrt{100}=10\,V\).

questions.question: In a closed organ pipe producing a musical note, an antinode will always be produced at

options.text: all the parts of between the ends of the pipe

questions.explanation: In a closed pipe, the closed end is a displacement node and the open end is a displacement antinode.

questions.question: What happens when a certain quantity of pure ice is completely changed to water at 0°C?

options.text: Latent heat is absorbed, the mass decreases and the volume increases.
latent heat is absorbed, the mass remains constant and the volume decreases.
latent heat is given out, the mass increases and the volume remains constant.
latent heat is given out, the mass remains constant and the volume decreases.

questions.explanation: Melting absorbs latent heat; mass remains the same. Ice has larger volume than water for the same mass, so volume decreases on melting.

questions.question: In the diagram above, P, Q and R are vectors. Which of the following options gives the correct relationship between the vectors?
questions.explanation: The vectors are arranged head-to-tail in a closed triangle, so their vector sum is zero: \(\vec P+\vec Q+\vec R=0\).

questions.question: If two parallel conductors carry currents flowing in the same direction, the conductors will

options.text: both move in the same direction
have no effect on each other

questions.explanation: Parallel currents in the same direction attract due to the magnetic force between the conductors.

questions.question:
Which of the following correctly explain(s) why a green leaf appears green in a bright daylight?
I. It absorbs only the green component of sunlight
II. It absorbs all colours in sunlight except green
III. It reflects only the green component of sunlight
questions.explanation: A leaf appears green because it reflects green light and absorbs most other colours; thus II and III are correct, I is false.

questions.question: Which of the following factors has no effect on the e.m.f of a primary cell?
questions.explanation: Cell emf depends on electrode materials, electrolyte, and temperature, but not on the physical size of the cell (size affects internal resistance/capacity).

questions.question: When the bottom tip of a vibrating tuning fork is held in contact with a wooden box, a louder sound is heard. This phenomenon is known as
questions.explanation: The box resonates with the tuning fork frequency, increasing amplitude and loudness.

questions.question: A particle of mass M which at rest splits up into two. If the mass and the velocity of one of the particles are m and v respectively, calculate the velocity of the second particle
questions.explanation: Initial momentum is zero. After splitting, momenta are equal and opposite: \(mv = (M-m)u\). So \(u=\frac{mv}{M-m}\).

questions.question: The electrochemical equivalent of silver is 0.0012 g/C. If 36.0 g of silver is to be deposited by electrolysis on a surface by passing a steady current for 5.0 minutes, the current must be
The principle of operation of an induction coil is based on __
questions.explanation: Induction coils work by electromagnetic induction (Faraday’s law).

questions.question: A radioactive sample initially contains N atoms. After three half-lives the number of atoms that have disintegrated is
questions.explanation: Remaining after 3 half-lives: \(N\left(\tfrac{1}{2}\right)^3=\tfrac{N}{8}\). Disintegrated: \(N-\tfrac{N}{8}=\tfrac{7N}{8}\).

questions.question: Mercury is suitable as a barometric fluid because it

options.text: is several times denser than water
is a good conductor of heat

questions.explanation: High density makes the barometer column short and practical.

questions.question: Which of the following features is NOT a characteristic of natural radioactivity?

options.text: radioactivity is exhibited only by the element of mass number greater than 206
The radioactivity of an element is affected by electric and magnetic fields in the surroundings.
Radioactive substances emit three types of radiations α-rays, β-rays and γ-rays.

questions.explanation: Radioactivity is not affected by external electric/magnetic fields (though fields can deflect charged radiation after emission).

questions.question: Which of the following is a correct explanation of the INERTIA of a body?

options.text: Reluctance to start moving at rest and its reluctance to stop moving once it has begun move
Reluctance to start moving and its readiness to stop moving once it has begun to move

questions.explanation: Inertia is resistance to changes in state of motion: reluctance to start moving and to stop once moving.

questions.question: If the force on a charge of 0.2 coulomb in an electric field intensity the field is
questions.explanation: The question statement is incomplete in the image (missing the force value), so the field intensity cannot be calculated.

questions.question: The point beyond which a stretched spring does not return to its original length is called the
questions.explanation: Beyond the elastic limit, deformation becomes permanent and the spring does not return to original length.

questions.question:
Which of the following statements is applicable to a real image formed by a concave mirror?
I. It can be observed on a screen
II. It is always inverted and in front of the mirror
III. It only seems to exist
IV. It is formed by the actual converging of rays of light
questions.explanation: A real image can be formed on a screen (I), is inverted and in front of the mirror (II), and results from actual convergence of rays (IV). III describes virtual images.

questions.question: Which of the following does not cause a reduction of the surface tension of water?
questions.explanation: Soap, detergents, and alcohol reduce water surface tension. Grease does not act as a surfactant in water to reduce its surface tension.

questions.question: In what range of temperature is the expansion of water anomalous?
questions.explanation: Water shows anomalous expansion between 0°C and 4°C (it contracts when heated from 0°C to 4°C).

missingQuestions: Questions beyond 40 are not present in the uploaded images for this year.
Question 13, 19, 20, 28, 36 are incomplete or contain unreadable/ambiguous information in the provided images (not enough to choose uniquely).
